alert.note: Alert for Golden Valley; Judith Gap; Melville Foothills; Musselshell; Northeastern Yellowstone; Northern Big Horn; Northern Park; Northern Stillwater; Northern Sweet Grass; Southern Wheatland; Southwestern Yellowstone (Montana) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Wind Chill Advisory issued January 16 at 1:08AM MST until January 16 at 11:00AM MST by NWS Billings
info.description: ...WIND CHILL ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 11 AM MST THIS MORNING... ...WINTER STORM WATCH REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM THIS EVENING THROUGH THURSDAY AFTERNOON... * WHAT...For the Wind Chill Advisory, very cold wind chills as low as 35 below zero. For the Winter Storm Watch, heavy snow possible. Total snow accumulations between 4 and 9 inches possible. Greatest amounts are expected to be north of I-90. * WHERE...Portions of central and south central Montana. * WHEN...For the Wind Chill Advisory, until 11 AM MST this morning. For the Winter Storm Watch, from this evening through Thursday afternoon. * IMPACTS...The dangerously cold wind chills could cause frostbite on exposed skin in as little as 10 minutes. Regarding the winter storm watch, roads will likely become snowpacked, slick and hazardous, with areas of poor visibility. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Gusty southwest to west winds may cause local blowing and drifting snow today. Areas most likely to be affected include I-90 from Livingston to Big Timber, and US-191 from Big Timber to Harlowton. Visibility may be reduced to under 2 miles at times. Local rural roads may also see drifting. Drivers should use caution.
info.instruction: During the wind chill advisory, people are urged to stay indoors until conditions improve. If you must go outside, dress in layers. Several layers of clothes will keep you warmer than a single heavy coat. Cover exposed skin to reduce your risk of frostbite or hypothermia. People may want to delay all travel if possible during the winter storm watch period. If travel is absolutely necessary, drive with extreme caution and be prepared for sudden changes in visibility. Keep track of the latest forecast updates.
